Sea levels around the world are
rising. http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/sealevel.html 'Current sea-
level rise' potentially affects human populations (e.g., those living in coastal
regions and on islands) {{AR4|WG1|chapter=5|section=Section
5.5.1: Introductory Remarks|section-url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch5s5-
5.html#5-5-1 }} and the natural environment (e.g., marine ecosystems). {{citation
 | author= Fischlin author2=et al. chapter=Section 4.4.9: Oceans and shallow

}} Between 1870 and 2004, global average sea levels rose . {{cite journal

measurements show an average annual rise in sea level of 1.7 Â± 0.3 mm
per year, with satellite data showing a rise of 3.3 Â± 0.4 mm per year
from 1993 to 2009, {{cite journal |first1= Robert J. |last1= Nicholls

1 Synthesis Report, Section 1.1: Observations of climate change], in .
 It is unclear whether the increased rate reflects an increase in the
underlying long-term trend. IPCC, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains1.html#1-
1 Synthesis Report, Section 1.1: Observations of climate change], in ;
{{cite web
 | year=2009 author=Dahlman, L. title=NOAA Climate Portal: ClimateWatch
 | Magazine: Climate Change: Global Sea Level url=http://www.climatewatch.noaa.gov/article/2009/climate-change-sea-
 | level publisher=NOAA Climate Services accessdate=2011-07-29
}} 

Two main factors contributed to observed sea level rise. IPCC, [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-5-
1.html FAQ 5.1: Is Sea Level Rising?], in .  The first is thermal
expansion: as ocean water warms, it expands. Albritton et al.,
[http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg1/013.htm#b4 Technical Summary, Box 2:
What causes sea level to change?], in .  The second is from the
contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of
water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets.

Sea level rise is one of several lines of evidence that support the view that
the climate has recently warmed. Solomon et al., [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/tssts-3-
4.html Technical Summary, Section 3.4 Consistency Among Observations], in ;
Hegerl et al., [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains1-
3.html Executive summary, Section 1.3: Consistency of changes in physical and
biological systems with warming], in .  The global community of climate
scientists confirms that it is very likely that human-induced (anthropogenic)
warming contributed to the sea level rise observed in the latter half of the
20th century. Hegerl et al., [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch9s9-
es.html Chapter 9: Understanding and Attributing Climate Change], in . 

Sea level rise is expected to continue for centuries. In 2007,
the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) projected that during the
21st century, sea level will rise another , but these numbers do not include
"uncertainties in climate-carbon cycle feedbacks nor do they include the full
effects of changes in ice sheet flow". IPCC,
[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3.html Topic 3], [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains3-2-
1.html Section 3.2.1: 21st century global changes], [http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-
report/ar4/syr/ar4_syr.pdf p. 45], in .  More recent projections assessed
by the US National Research Council (2010) suggest possible
sea level rise over the 21st century of between .

On the timescale of centuries to millennia, the melting of ice sheets could
result in even higher sea level rise. Partial deglaciation of the Greenland ice
sheet, and possibly the West Antarctic ice sheet, could contribute or more to
sea level rise. IPCC,
[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/spm.html Summary for
Policymakers], [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/spmsspm-c-15-magnitudes-
of.html Section C. Current knowledge about future impacts â Magnitudes of
impact] in .

Work by a team led by Veerabhadran Ramanathan of the Scripps Institution of
Oceanography suggests that a quick way to stave off impending sea level rise is
to cut emissions of short-lived climate warmers such as methane and soot. [-
http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/349626/description/News_in_Brief_Cut-
s_in_some_greenhouse_gases_could_slow_sea_level_rise Cuts in some greenhouse
gases could slow sea level rise]; "Methane, ozone and other short-lived
pollutants have a big impact on ocean heights" April 12, 2013 Vol.183 #9 Science
News
